questions.question_text: When specifying a trigger action for an Alarm Definition, what two alarm state changes are available to be triggered on? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
@platin : when you create a new alarm, you set general settings, Triggers and Actions. When you are configuring actions, there are columns showing status changes but icons are only used. Green tick to yellow triangle (normal to warning), warning to critical, critical to warning and warning to normal. These are valid ones. Just two are listed in the choices for this question. If you check the columns in the screenshot in the below link, you will get it :

https://virtuallymikebrown.com/2011/11/03/add-e-mail-alerts-to-all-40-default-vsphere-4-1-alarms/

The answer is B and D.

The available alarm state changes are:
1. Normal to Warning.
2. Warning to Critical.
3. Critical to Warning.
4. Warning to Normal.
https://geek-university.com/vmware-esxi/create-alarms/
B and D correct. Passed with 500/500 today

A good solution to remember this is listing the states like this: normal-warning-critical
If any or this options are not correlative in the sequence, the answer is incorrect.
This is very usefull to me, i hope that for you too

comments.content: Just checked against my production system. You can go from normal to warning, warning to critical, critical to warning, and warning to normal. You can't skip and go from normal to critical or critical to normal. So the answers are correct. B & D.

questions.question_text:
A vSphere administrator takes a snapshot before logging into a VM to preserve the current state in case of a problem.
Assuming this process is repeated every day for over 30 days, what two results will happen? (Choose two.)

choices.C: The administrator will have backups for the entire month.
choices.A: The virtual machine's performance will decrease.
choices.D: The administrator has successfully cloned the VM 30 times.
choices.B: The virtual machine can end up consuming more space on the datastore than assigned.

discussion.content: AB is correct. Snapshot is not a backup, nor a successful clone.

questions.question_text: Which state does VMware recommend an ESXi host be in before removing the ESXi host from a DRS cluster?

discussion.content: One can disconnect and remove a host if you don't want to migrate or power off all the VMs on it to put it in maintenance mode. Therefore, "disconnect" is also a correct answer.
